equipment: A standard armchair (approximately 46 cm in height) and a clear walkway with a mark at 3 meters.
instructions: Begin by having the patient sit with their back against the chair and their hands on the arms of the chair. Any assistive device to be used should be within reach of the patient. On the command "go", have the patient rise from the chair, walk 3 meters at a comfortable and safe pace, turn around and walk back to the chair, and sit down. Timing begins at the instruction to "go" and ends when the patient's buttocks touch the seat. One practice trial should be permitted. Any assistive device used should be kept constant between tests if the results are to be compared.
mcid_mdc:
MCID = Minimally Clinically Important Difference, MDC = Minimal Detectable Change

Alzheimer's Disease: MDC = 4.09s
Stroke: MDC = 2.9s
Parkinson's Disease: MDC = 3.5s
Spinal Cord Injury: MDC= 10.8s

These are published values for specific populations and provide guidance if the patient does not have the listed condition.
overview: The Timed Up & Go (TUG) Test is a performance measure used to assess a patient's ability to stand, walk, turn, and sit. It can be employed to assess mobility, balance, walking ability, and fall risk.
population: The intended population includes the following conditions:  Geriatrics, Hip Fracture, Parkinson's Disease, Multiple Sclerosis, Alzheimer's, Stroke, Knee and Hip Arthroplasty, and Huntington's Disease.
references:
1. Mathias S, Nayak US, Isaacs B. Balance in elderly patients: the "get-up and go" test. Arch Phys Med Rehabil. 1986;67(6):387-389
2. Podsiadlo D, Richardson S. The timed "Up & Go": a test of basic functional mobility for frail elderly persons. J Am Geriatr Soc. 1991;39(2):142-148. doi:10.1111/j.1532-5415.1991.tb01616.x
3. Ries JD, Echternach JL, Nof L, et al. Test-retest reliability and minimal detectable change scores for the timed "up & go" test, the six-minute walk test, and gait speed in people with Alzheimer disease. Phys Ther. 2009;89(6):569-579. doi:10.2522/ptj.20080258
4. Flansbjer UB, Holmbäck AM, Downham D, et al. Reliability of gait performance tests in men and women with hemiparesis after stroke. J Rehabil Med. 2005;37(2):75-82. doi:10.1080/16501970410017215
5. Huang SL, Hsieh CL, Wu RM, et al. Minimal detectable change of the timed "up & go" test and the dynamic gait index in people with Parkinson disease [published correction appears in Phys Ther. 2014 Jul;94(7):1056]. Phys Ther. 2011;91(1):114-121. doi:10.2522/ptj.20090126
6. Lam T, Noonan VK, Eng JJ; SCIRE Research Team. A systematic review of functional ambulation outcome measures in spinal cord injury. Spinal Cord. 2008;46(4):246-254. doi:10.1038/sj.sc.3102134
7. Shumway-Cook A, Brauer S, Woollacott M. Predicting the probability for falls in community-dwelling older adults using the Timed Up & Go Test. Phys Ther. 2000;80(9):896-903.
8. Andersson AG, Kamwendo K, Seiger A, et al. How to identify potential fallers in a stroke unit: validity indexes of 4 test methods. J Rehabil Med. 2006;38(3):186-191. doi:10.1080/16501970500478023
9. Thomas JI, Lane JV. A pilot study to explore the predictive validity of 4 measures of falls risk in frail elderly patients. Arch Phys Med Rehabil. 2005;86(8):1636-1640. doi:10.1016/j.apmr.2005.03.004
10. Dite W, Connor HJ, Curtis HC. Clinical identification of multiple fall risk early after unilateral transtibial amputation. Arch Phys Med Rehabil. 2007;88(1):109-114. doi:10.1016/j.apmr.2006.10.015
11. Nocera JR, Stegemöller EL, Malaty IA, et al. Using the Timed Up & Go test in a clinical setting to predict falling in Parkinson's disease. Arch Phys Med Rehabil. 2013;94(7):1300-1305. doi:10.1016/j.apmr.2013.02.020
12. Dibble LE, Lange M. Predicting falls in individuals with Parkinson disease: a reconsideration of clinical balance measures. J Neurol Phys Ther. 2006;30(2):60-67. doi:10.1097/01.npt.0000282569.70920.dc
13. Arnold CM, Faulkner RA. The history of falls and the association of the timed up and go test to falls and near-falls in older adults with hip osteoarthritis. BMC Geriatr. 2007;7:17. doi:10.1186/1471-2318-7-17
14. Whitney SL, Marchetti GF, Schade A, et al. The sensitivity and specificity of the Timed "Up & Go" and the Dynamic Gait Index for self-reported falls in persons with vestibular disorders. J Vestib Res. 2004;14(5):397-409.
score_calculation: Timing begins at the instruction to "go" and ends when the patient's buttocks touch the seat. One practice trial should be permitted. Document the elapsed time and the assistive device and/or brace used.
score_interpretation:
Cut-off scores indicating risk of falls by population:
Community dwelling adults > 13.5s
Older stroke patients > 14s
Frail elderly > 32.6s
Lower Limb Amputees > 19s
Parkinson's Disease > 7.95s
Hip Osteoarthritis > 10s
Vestibular Disorders > 11.1s
